awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A tool to automate a narrative patient summary of the medical chart for outpatient physicians
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact /commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a machine learning-enabled medical record summarization tool designed to provide a narrative summary that can aid physicians in patient care. On average, physicians spend just 3 minutes reviewing a patient’s medical record, and during this time they must interpret unstructured Electronic Health Records (EHR) that can make it difficult for physicians to identify information essential to patient care and diagnosis. By targeting the rich clinical data embedded in unstructured clinical notes, the proposed tool could provide clinically relevant information and a contextual understanding of a patient’s medical history. If successful, the proposed solution will reduce the data burden placed on doctors, mitigate the risk of missing valuable information that could affect patient diagnosis or lead to costly medical errors, and maximize downstream effects on patient outcomes. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to leverage advances in natural language processing (NLP) to assist doctors by automating the process of electronic health record review. The underlying innovation is an extractive-abstractive pipeline that determines what content in the medical record is the most salient and should be summarized through a transformer (a machine learning model). This project aims to advance this summarization tool to more challenging use cases, primarily summarizing the outpatient record, a task made challenging by the large scope of the data, clinical redundancies, different data structures, and sources inherent to outpatient data, all of which need to be accounted for in model training and validation. Objectives include to 1) developing an outpatient summarization model and demonstrating the ability to produce summaries that semantically match reference text with a high level of fluency, 2) validating the utility of artificial intelligence (AI)-generated outpatient summaries to provide significant value to physicians, 3) evaluating the ability of AI-generated summaries that provide information relevant to future patient visit through ablation study, and 4) incorporating checks for bias in the existing model.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
On average, physicians spend just 3 minutes reviewing a patient's medical record, and as a result often miss important information and follow-ups that lead to poor patient outcomes. This challenge has been exacerbated due to the large amount of data in the electronic health record (EHR) and limited interoperability across systems. Approximately 50% of patients discharged from hospitals experience medical errors and 36% of follow-ups are missed after lab exams. Yet EHR use is taking up an increasing amount of provider time, with a comprehensive survey of primary care physicians finding EHRs ate up nearly 62% of time spent on patient interactions. Increasing EHR use is associated with provider burnout, which negatively affects patient care, provider health, and the overall economy. Abstractive Health has developed a machine learning-enabled medical record summarization tool designed to quickly provide a narrative summary that can aid physicians in patient care. By using natural language processing, we target the rich clinical data embedded in unstructured clinical notes, deriving a contextual understanding of a patient's medical history from hundreds of pages of records which can include handwritten scan documents. This AI-based summarization solution improves the workload of physicians by decreasing documentation burdens, decreasing critical patient safety risks, preventing costly medical errors, and enhancing the overall patient care experience.

Abstractive Health's core model was trained with 10,000 real and complete medical charts and their corresponding physician summaries. Generated summaries mirrored the structure of a manually written physician summary and captured 97% of relevant follow-up information in a patient's chart. We further developed this model using an additional 1600 highly curated records, and the resulting AI-generated summaries had better automated evaluative scores than the physician-written reference ones. Additionally, 92% of the AI-generated summaries were classified as acceptable quality and usefulness, and none of the summaries were classified with critical patient safety risk. The summarization tool led to physicians being 38.3% more knowledgeable of a patient's medical record.

We integrated the large language model (LLM) into a software application for summarizing a patient's medical record. We demonstrated that our AI summarization software tool had excellent usability for physicians. We expanded our application for physicians by pulling in outside medical records for summarization from across the United States by building integration with the national health information exchange (HIE) of Carequality - such that if a patient had lived at multiple locations, our tool captured the patient's comprehensive medical history. Twenty-three physicians searched through our platform and 86.1% of the time the physicians were able to successfully find a comprehensive patient record; of patients found, we pulled an average of 101 external records for each of their patients. In developing our LLM and software application, we were mindful to avoid introducing biases; out of 150 test summaries evaluated, none of the summaries had any forms of biases.
